stem: Complete the following clinical statement regarding pericarditis assessment findings.
template: A key assessment finding in pericarditis is {{blank1}}, often described as a {{blank2}} sound upon auscultation.

rationale.correct: A pericardial friction rub is a hallmark finding in pericarditis, resulting from the inflamed pericardial layers rubbing against each other during cardiac cycles. The inflammation causes the normally smooth pericardial surfaces to become roughened, creating the characteristic sound. This sound is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope, with the patient leaning forward. The scratchy, high-pitched quality of the rub is due to the grating movement of the inflamed pericardial layers.
rationale.incorrect: Distant heart sounds indicate possible fluid accumulation, such as a pericardial effusion. Bounding pulses are not typically associated with pericarditis. A low-pitched, rumbling heart sound is more indicative of valvular stenosis. A musical, blowing sound suggests valvular regurgitation, not pericarditis.

clinicalPearls: A pericardial friction rub may be transient, so auscultate frequently in suspected cases of pericarditis.
Differentiating a pericardial friction rub from a pleural friction rub involves having the patient hold their breath; a pericardial rub will persist, while a pleural rub will diminish.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming all chest pain is cardiac in origin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the characteristics of the pain and associated findings to differentiate between pericarditis, myocardial ischemia, and other causes.

mnemonic.title: FRICTION
mnemonic.expansion: Friction Rub Indicates Cardiac Trouble Involves Obvious Noises

reviewUnits.heading: Key Concept Review
reviewUnits.body: Pericarditis involves inflammation of the pericardium, often resulting in chest pain, a pericardial friction rub, and ECG changes. Common causes include viral infections, autoimmune disorders, and post-myocardial infarction. Assessment involves careful cardiac auscultation, ECG monitoring, and inflammatory markers. Treatment focuses on pain management, reducing inflammation (NSAIDs, colchicine), and addressing the underlying cause. Complications include pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.
